body: the live board works nice. here is my codes ``` python pandas_logger = mx.callback.PandasLogger(batch_size, 5) live = mx.callback.LiveLearningCurve(pandas_logger, 'accuracy', 5) ``` and add the following into `model.fit` ``` **mx.callback.args_wrapper(pandas_logger, live) ``` but i feel it is too complicate, for example, i need to specify 5 twice, and even for `eval_metric='acc'`, i need to specify `'accuracy'` when creating `LiveLearningCurve` i also changed the figure style to make it slightly better, namely ``` python self.fig.circle(self.x1,self.y1, size=1.5, line_alpha=.2, legend="train") self.x2 = [] self.y2 = [] self.fig.line(self.x2,self.y2, line_color='green', line_width=2, legend="validation") self.fig.legend.location = "bottom_right" ``` here is screenshot
@piiswrong: ok. One more thing: can arguments to mxnet symbols be tuples of tuples? If not, will just use a single tuple to represent padding.
No. Only support tuple of unsigned. You can add support to your own type by writing parsers though

exmaple/module/lstm_bucketing.py
example/rnn/char-rnn.ipynb
Would you recommend that I just use a tuple of unsigned for the padding? Or add a parser? (if so, in which file are parsers defined?)
Please use tuple if it's enough. just to be consistent

IMO, I think there is a bug with the source code, since I am following the rnn example to construct a cnn+rnn symbol. It goes well when I just run the cnn while the error raised when I add RNN to cnn. As using RNN we need to pass the init state from the DataIter, So d_src[slice_idx] is actually a list of [data, init_h, init_cell] rather than a mx.nd array(which is the data used in cnn experiements)
Please post your data iter
@DCYN should be fixed with https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3599
data=[x] -> data=x

This is a Linux question. Set it from command line.
for example:

``` bash
export MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE=NaiveEngine
```
I think you should print the provided data shape and the feed data shape. Make sure they are matched.
Thanks for catching my bugs and the visual improvements, Mu.  I've got some more examples and a Module patch I'm about to merge in -- I'll add these.

We probably want a checkbox to toggle between wall clock and number of epochs because
1. people have different hardware setup with different speed, which makes results non comparable.
2. systems sometimes slowdown randomly and could be confusing if reflected on training curve

@piiswrong a constructor switch between epoch and wall-clock is easy to do.  I'll add that.  I like wall-clock for comparing different hyper-parameter settings though because what you really care about is how long it actually takes to get an answer.  It would be awesome to have a GUI checkbox that toggles, but that's actually fairly complicated due to a limitation in bokeh that doesn't let you dynamically swap axis ranges at runtime.

@mli Yes the constructor is too complicated right now.  I'm going to make the LiveLearningCurve instantiate a PandasLogger by default if you don't specify one.  This makes the common case simpler.  If you want multiple live charts, you'll be able to do that more efficiently by sharing a pandaslogger.  I'll push the new proposed interface soon and would love feedback.

@kevinthesun Thanks a lot! We do not directly push to the main repo. You can make a clone and then submit a pull request. See [the mxnet doc](http://mxnet.io/community/contribute.html#submit-pull-request) and [the github doc](https://help.github.com/articles/about-pull-requests/).

Well, not as easily as I thought. Seems like the problem is using multiple gpu except in my toy script even sgd gives the error. so same error for model 5 and 6 below.

```
library(mxnet)

X <- as.matrix(iris[,1:4])
y <- as.integer(iris[,5] == 'virginica')

data <- mx.symbol.Variable('data')
data <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden = 1)
data <- mx.symbol.Activation(data, act_type = 'tanh')
logreg <- mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data)

model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(logreg, X, y, learning.rate = 0.1)

model2 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(logreg, X, y, optimizer = 'adam')

n.gpu <- 1
devices <- lapply(0:(n.gpu-1), function(i) {
  mx.gpu(i)
})
model3 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(logreg, X, y, ctx=devices, learning.rate = 0.1)
model4 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(logreg, X, y, ctx=devices, optimizer = 'adam')

n.gpu <- 4
devices <- lapply(0:(n.gpu-1), function(i) {
  mx.gpu(i)
})
model5 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(logreg, X, y, ctx=devices, learning.rate=0.1)
model6 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(logreg, X, y, ctx=devices, optimizer = 'adam')
```

```
Error in eval(substitute(expr), envir, enclos) : 
  expecting an external pointer
```

Thank U guys @piiswrong  @shuokay . It finally works.
Actually Mxnet need list input for mx.io.DataBatch:
    x = [mx.ndarray.array(x)] + self.init_state_arrays
    y = [mx.ndarray.array(y)]
    self.current_batch = mx.io.DataBatch(data=x, label=y, pad=0, index=None)

When it come to:
    x = [mx.ndarray.array(x)] + self.init_state_arrays
    y = mx.ndarray.array(y)
    self.current_batch = mx.io.DataBatch(data=x, label=y, pad=0, index=None)
Then: 
    Check failed: (shape[0]) >= (end) Slice end index out of range

I found that the [devdocs](http://devdocs.io/) website has a very nice style for documentations. It also works well with mobile devices. If someone would like to adapt that to MXNet documentation, the source code of devdocs is [hosted here](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs).

I experienced the same kind of error yesterday and the problem ended up being that I'd compiled lapack with gcc 4.x but had compiled torch with 5.x. The "undefined reference to..." is a huge hint that's what's going on as I've been slowly upgrading my (Gentoo) system and I've hit that error countless times. That may not be your problem but I figured I'd post a potential solution in case it helps someone.

softmax_label is the default name of data iterator's output. If you are not using that name you need to change your data iter.
That said its easier to just do
`MAEr = mx.symbol.MAERegressionOutput(data=fc3, name='softmax')`
I have opened a new pull request. If you have chance to take a look at the changes and test them, it would be nice!

On Oct 20, 2016 6:25 PM, "Zhenlin" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Thanks for suggestion. I did some debug. Actually this is because if
> anaconda is installed with mkl, numpy and related python will call the mkl
> and iomp5 lib in anaconda which is pre-defined.
> find library=libiomp5.so [0]; searching
> search path=/root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/../../../..
> (RPATH from file /root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packag
> es/numpy/core/multiarray.so)
> trying file=/root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/
> core/../../../../libiomp5.so
> 
> Because of this, the old MKL version in anaconda will be initialized and
> loaded so when calling new API, it will be wrong.
> 62803: calling init: /root/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/
> site-packages/numpy/core/../../../../libmkl_avx2.so
> 62803:
> 
> 62803: python: error: symbol lookup error: undefined symbol:
> scalable_malloc (fatal)
> MKL Build:20160413
> [18:49:27] /home/zhenlin/Mxnet/upstream/intel-mxnet/intel-mxnet/dmlc-
> core/include/dmlc/logging.h:235: [18:49:27] src/operator/mkl/mkl_memory.cc:51:
> Check fai
> led: (status) == (E_SUCCESS) Failed creation convert_to_int with status -1
> for buffer: fwd_filter_data @ MKLConvolutionOp
> 
> [18:49:27] /home/zhenlin/Mxnet/upstream/intel-mxnet/intel-mxnet/dmlc-
> core/include/dmlc/logging.h:235: [18:49:27] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:306:
> [18:49:27] src/operator/mkl/mkl_memory.cc:51: Check failed: (status) ==
> (E_SUCCESS) Failed creation convert_to_int with status -1 for buffer:
> fwd_filter_data @ MKL
> ConvolutionOp
> 
> It is not issue of mkldnn compatible with anaconda. It is the issue when
> installing 2 different MKL version in system to cause annoying. The quick
> way to resolve this is remove mkl in anaconda until anaconda integrate the
> latest MKL2017. Pls refer to https://www.continuum.io/blog/
> developer-blog/anaconda-25-release-now-mkl-optimizations
> 
> Since I believe anaconda will integrate the new MKL2017 soon, this issue
> will disappear automatically. I will put this into README as known issue.
> Also I will continue to look at this to see if have better w/a.
> 
> But I think this should not block the PR merge, right? Pls let me know.
> 
> —

@anthony-han  Has your problem be solved? It seems #3055 just solved the problem of cpu memory leak, but for gpu predict, the problem still exists @piiswrong

@feiyulv I think you can change src/storage/storage.cc line 76
from
`ptr = new storage::GPUPooledStorageManager();`
to
`ptr = new storage::NaiveStorageManager<storage::GPUDeviceStorage>();`

It seems that GPUPooledStorageManager will use up nearly all gpu memory, for speedup

In my opinion, naivestorgemanager is more intuitive and convenient; sometimes i just need to launch multiple jobs on a single gpu, and by using gpupooledstoragemanager, the processes often end up with memory allocation error (size of input images change and the memory rarely can be reused). I think a better strategy should be introduced @piiswrong

mxnet.base.MXNetError: InferShape Error in softmax's label argument
Corresponding keyword of symbol: softmax_label

I have find reason from im2rec.py.
cgroup.add_argument('--exts', type=list,default=['.jpeg', '.jpg'],
                        help='list of acceptable image extensions.')
change to
cgroup.add_argument('--exts', type=list, action='append',default=['.jpeg', '.jpg'],
                        help='list of acceptable image extensions.')
OK!

@thirdwing

> However, I can install mxnet directly from the repository at https://cran.rstudio.com

I don' think you can install from CRAN, it has been published on CRAN.

Another issue is that currently we only provide the GPU binary for Windows. There is no update on Windows CPU version.
The label dimension might be different from different kaldi run. @yzhang87 Maybe we should add comments on how to read out this parameter from kaldi outputs.
@wd929 "index 1936 is out of bounds for axis 0 with size 1936", I think it means you need increase the your label dim. You can check final.occs in kaldi model file for the total number of labels.

@kevinthesun Thanks! That is one of the reference style that (I think) looks good and also works one mobile phone. My guess is starting from an existing working stylesheet and adapt that to our existing theme (e.g. overall color scheme and make the front page works properly) is easier than modify our existing style trying to mimic others, because it can be hard to cover all aspects and glitches and inconsistency throughout browsers and devices. But I'm not an expert in front end so my words might not make sense. :)

I just created a new, clean VM (Azure windows 2012 R Server), installed RStudio, and ran the following:

install.packages("drat", repos="https://cran.rstudio.com")
drat:::addRepo("dmlc")
install.packages("mxnet")
library(mxnet)

model <- mx.model.load('trainedmodel',600)

where 'trainedmodel' is a model that I trained on a GPU linux machine (Ubuntu 14.04 with 4 gpus). When I try loading the model on my OSX machine, it works without problems. But on the brand new, clean windows machine, I get this:

## Error: Failed loading Op convolution0 of type Convolution: Cannot find argument 'cudnn_off', Possible Arguments:

kernel : Shape(tuple), required
    convolution kernel size: (y, x)
stride : Shape(tuple), optional, default=(1,1)
    convolution stride: (y, x)
dilate : Shape(tuple), optional, default=(1,1)
    convolution dilate: (y, x)
pad : Shape(tuple), optional, default=(0,0)
    pad for convolution: (y, x)
num_filter : int (non-negative), required
    convolution filter(channel) number
num_group : int (non-negative), optional, default=1
    Number of groups partition. This option is not supported by CuDNN, you can use SliceChannel to num_group,apply convolution and concat instead to achieve the same need.
workspace : long (non-negative), optional, default=512
    Tmp workspace for convolution (MB).
no_bias : boolean, optional, default=False
    Whether to disable bias parameter.

I tried downloading the Inception-BN pre-trained model and loading it, too. I got the same error.

One more clue: in looking back at the RStudio output, it looks like drat is pulling an older version of mxnet:

This is the output after 
install.packages("mxnet")

trying URL 'https://dmlc.github.io/drat/bin/windows/contrib/3.2/mxnet_0.7.zip'
Content type 'application/zip' length 14226758 bytes (13.6 MB)
downloaded 13.6 MB

It is because the windows is too old. The CPU version of mxnet for Windows
is built in May.

What would it take to update it to a newer version? I'm ok with a GPU version, but I would like to be able to use the R installer.
Does it still cost more time when you run it for the second time?

I think we can't host the GPU version in drat. CPU version is more universal.

If you need GPU version, I am afraid you need to build the R package by yourself.
The instruction is here: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/docs/get_started/setup.md#installing-mxnet-on-a-gpu

@pluskid  It is a good suggestion we should use a template, but right now since most contents are completed, I prefer modifying the existing website. I have fixed the index page to make it work well for mobile device. The change has been merged into master so you can check it out.
